title: Chess Vocabulary
description: Chess terms, strategy, and piece movements

questions.question: What does 'checkmate' mean in chess?
options: The king is under attack and cannot escape, ending the game
A player resigns voluntarily
The king is in danger but can escape
Both players agree to a draw

questions.question: What is 'castling' in chess?
options: Moving a bishop diagonally across the board
Capturing an opponent's piece
Promoting a pawn to a queen
A special move involving the king and a rook switching positions

questions.question: What does 'stalemate' mean?
options: A draw where the player to move has no legal moves but is not in check
When time runs out
One player has won decisively
A situation where both players are in check

questions.question: What is 'en passant' in chess?
options: A special pawn capture where a pawn takes an adjacent pawn that just moved two squares
Moving a knight in an L-shape
Placing a piece back on the board after capture
A defensive move to protect the king

questions.question: What is a 'gambit' in chess?
options: A defensive formation of pieces
An opening strategy where a player sacrifices material for an advantage
A quick victory in under ten moves
A move that puts the opponent in check

questions.question: What does 'fianchetto' mean in chess?
options: Capturing a piece while in check
A small chess piece
A type of endgame technique
Developing a bishop to the long diagonal by moving the knight's pawn one square

questions.question: What is a 'fork' in chess?
options: A move where one piece attacks two or more enemy pieces simultaneously
Trading pieces of equal value
Splitting the board in half
A type of opening move

questions.question: What does 'pin' mean as a chess tactic?
options: An attack on a piece that cannot move without exposing a more valuable piece behind it
Placing all pawns in a row
Fastening a piece to the board
A move that forces a draw

questions.question: What is 'promotion' in chess?
options: Moving a piece to a more important square
When a pawn reaches the opposite end of the board and becomes another piece
Elevating a player's ranking
Winning a tournament round

questions.question: What is the 'endgame' in chess?
options: The final phase of the game when few pieces remain on the board
When a player resigns
The very first move of a game
A tiebreaker round

questions.question: What does 'Zugzwang' mean in chess?
options: A situation where any move a player makes will worsen their position
A powerful attacking move
A surprise checkmate
A defensive wall of pawns

questions.question: What is a 'skewer' in chess?
options: A row of pawns protecting the king
A simultaneous attack on the king and queen
A technique for fast play
An attack on a valuable piece that forces it to move, exposing a less valuable piece behind it

questions.question: What does 'blitz' mean in chess?
options: A very long, slow game
A game played without a board
A fast-paced game with very short time controls
A game played by correspondence

questions.question: What is a 'sacrifice' in chess?
options: Losing a game on purpose
Refusing to make a move
Deliberately giving up a piece to gain a strategic advantage
Trading queens at the start of a game

questions.question: What is the 'opening' in chess?
options: A gap in the opponent's pawn structure
The hole in the center of the board
The first capture of the game
The initial phase of the game where players develop their pieces
